html:
NEW YORK, Nov 2 (IFR) - IFR is hosting a US ECM Roundtable titled “SPACs at a Crossroads” on Wednesday November 17 at 12:30pm. The event will assess the regulatory landscape and funding conditions for SPAC IPOs and PIPEs. Please take a moment to register for the event.

We are also inviting banks to pitch for the 2021 IFR Awards . ECM award categories cover IPOs, follow-ons, CBs and SPACs completed throughout the year in the US and LatAm.

Amazon-backed EV pickup maker Rivian Automotive reignited the US new issue market by moving ahead this evening with its blockbuster $8.37bn Nasdaq IPO, a deal already largely spoken for with orders from a who’s who of heavy-hitters.

It’s only the first of the month but Rivian leads an already overflowing November deal docket that now includes 17 live IPOs seeking to raise nearly $12bn combined.

This comes as funding opportunities are narrowing in the twilight of 2021 and as bankers are seemingly trying to get as many deals done as possible before Thanksgiving on November 25.

Rivian, one of six IPO launches today, plans to sell 135m primary shares or 15%–16% of the company at $57–$62 for pricing Tuesday, November 9.

The offering will easily rank as the biggest US IPO of the year, topping March’s $4.6bn NYSE offering from Korean e-commerce firm Coupang.

Not only that, Rivian’s IPO will likely be bigger than Uber Technologies’ $8.1bn NYSE debut in 2019, the biggest since Alibaba’s $22bn US IPO in 2014.

These datapoints again attest to just how much the EV opportunity has captured the imagination of investors in recent times, thanks in large part to the cult-like following of Elon Musk and Rivian rival/comp Tesla (whose share price has conveniently soared 33% in the past six sessions, including an 8.5% gain today).

Raising $8.4bn is probably not going to be a tall order for Rivian.

A powerhouse group of backers including Amazon, T. Rowe Price, Coatue Management, Franklin Templeton, Capital Research Global Investors, Third Point, Blackstone Alternative Asset Management, Dragoneer Investment and Soros Fund Management have agreed upfront to invest a combined $5bn or nearly 60% of the sum sought (as disclosed on the cover of the filing).

Amazon, which already has a 20% stake after leading a $2.5bn funding round in July, is putting in $200m of that sum.

Rivian is also setting aside 7% of the offering for eligible US customers with a standing vehicle pre-order.

It has pre-orders for 55,400 of its R1Ts and R1Ss in the US and Canada from customers that paid a $1,000 deposit.

The R1T is a two-row five-passenger pickup truck and the R1S a three-row seven-passenger SUV. More to the point and essentially underwriting/de-risking Rivian’s near-term outlook, Amazon has ordered 100,000 electric delivery vans, the largest EV order ever.

Like any EV investment, the challenge is delivering on production targets. To that end, the company began deliveries of the R1Ts in September (and has now delivered 156 of them) and expects to have produced 1,200 of the former and 25 of the R1Ss by the end of this year.

Though yet to generate much revenue, Rivian has the tailwinds of EV euphoria blowing at gale force levels, making it somewhat removed from day-to-day market concerns such as the increasingly hawkish bent of central banker globally. Some of the other 16 IPOs on the road may not be as fortunate.

The other big news (earlier today) was Berkshire Hathaway-backed Brazilian online lender Nu’s decision to set terms for its $3.2bn-plus NYSE/B3 IPO without yet formally launching the deal in the US/globally (look for it to price in December, see more below).

Meanwhile, 12 IPOs are slated to price this week, starting with Allbirds, Claros Mortgage Trust and DeliMobil tomorrow night.

Allbirds, the “sustainable” shoemaker, is well oversubscribed with good one-on-one conversions. Some of the initial feedback is that the deal looks cheap versus Swiss running shoemaker On, whose shares are up more than 50% since it debuted on the NYSE in September.

Despite the risks posed by this week’s FOMC meeting outcome and the likely start to its tapering of bond purchases, the S&P 500 edged 0.2% higher today to start the penultimate month of a manic year, taking year-to-date returns to a sprightly 22.9%.

One boost to confidence in the overall IPO market is that chipmaker GlobalFoundries, currently holding down the spot as this year’s third biggest IPO, has managed to overcome its poor debut last week to firm up in subsequent sessions. Today the shares rose 10.5% to $53.87, now comfortably above last week’s top-of-the-range $47.00 IPO price after initially breaking issue.

Nu wave

Though Rivian is going to beat it to the punch, Berkshire-Hathaway-backed Brazilian digital bank Nu is expected to launch its much-anticipated $3.2bn US/Brazil IPO shortly after Thanksgiving for pricing in early December.

This morning Nu publicly filed terms with the SEC and Brazil's CVM and said it expected to commence the offering once they had completed their respective review processes.

The eight-year-old fintech intends to launch the offering on Monday, November 29 before pricing the offering in early December, sources involved in the offering said. Though December is often perceived as a risky time to price a big IPO, we would note that both Airbnb and DoorDash managed to do so very successfully in the final month of 2020 (and these were last year’s two biggest IPOs to boot).

Nu is planning to sell a total of 289.2m ordinary shares, including some in the form of Brazilian Depositary Receipts (BDRs), on the NYSE and Brazil's B3 (via the BDRs in the case of the latter).

Each BDR is equivalent to six ordinary shares.

The Brazilian/BDR portion of the IPO is aimed largely at Nu's customers and will be marketed in a R$9.35–$10.29 range, while the range for the NYSE/global offering of ordinary shares will be $10–$11.

Today’s public filings follow Nu’s confirmation last week that it had filed confidentially with both regulators.

The CVM requires the marketing terms to be publicly displayed for at least 20 days, longer than the 15-day period required by the SEC.

"The Brazilian rules mean they have to have a filing with a range on it for a much longer period of time for the BDRs and they want their customers to get a lot of stock," one banker close to the deal said.

Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, Citigroup and NuInvest (Nu’s investment banking arm) are acting as global coordinators.

Of course, Nu is taking a leaf from July’s IPO of trading app Robinhood, which included a much bigger than usual retail/customer allocation (but didn’t work out that well given Robinhood shares are down 8% from their IPO price).

The Brazilian offering would give Nu's customers (subject to a cap) the opportunity to get one BDR each. They can participate via the Nu mobile app from November 9 to December 5 (presumably much like Robinhood’s IPO Access platform).

Nu, which in June raised $750m from a private round led by Berkshire Hathway at a $30bn, is seeking to go public at a $50bn valuation, leapfrogging other fast-growing Brazilian fintechs such as PagSeguro ($11.9bn), StoneCo ($10.5bn) and XP Inc ($18.3bn).

That would make Nu the third-largest company in Brazil’s Bovespa index by market cap, behind only Petrobras and Vale.

Founded in 2013, Nu has 48.1m customers in Brazil, Mexico and Colombia that use its digital-only banking platform for spending, saving, investing, borrowing and insurance. Nearly 30% of all Brazilians over the age of 15 are customers.

In Q3 2021, Nu more than tripled revenue to $480.9m. On average, it added 2.1m customers per month during the third quarter.

At your expense

If you ever wondered in an idle moment whether it was possible to use a four-letter obscenity in an S-1, the answer is yes.

Expensify’s prospectus uses the word “sh-t” on no less than four occasions, telling prospective investors that one of its rules for doing business is to “get sh-t done”.

We are not sure whether this constitutes a new non-GAAP metric, but somehow it got past the SEC’s overworked reviewers.

The Portland, Oregon-based expense management software firm this morning launched its up to $243.3m Nasdaq IPO, a deal it also hopes will further its lofty goal (and just one of them) to "save the world".

That is quite the, er, ambition for a 13-year-old company with $141m of annualized revenue and just the latest in a long line of payments/software IPOs.

Though the folks at shoemaker Allbirds must now be scratching their heads about what was so bad about their “sustainable public offering” line kiboshed by the SEC (no one just makes shoes these days), Expensify founder David Barrett piles it on with the big picture/social responsibility stuff and topics that seem only tangentially related to the investment premise here.

In a letter to investors (now mandatory, of course, for Silicon Valley types), Barrett argues that the company is no more just a corporate card than Google is just a search engine or Microsoft just an operating system (well, they are, aren’t they?).

“Both established an unassailable hold on one critical feature, and then built a moat around it a lightyear wide through ancillary features and services,” Barrett goes on.

“That deep gravity well of products and services inexorably tugs at every business in the solar system, gradually pulling them into orbit no matter where they started.

“We aim to do the same: to establish a dominant position in business expense management, and then surround it with a wide array of social, consumer, and prosumer functionality that tips everyone's trajectory towards our sun, a little more every day.”

Though at times it sounds like Barrett has had a bit too much sun (according to the company, humility is a “core quality” of the firm), he is not your grandfather’s CEO.

Famously Barrett ran afoul of his own company last year when he boldly emailed all its customers telling them a vote for President Trump was “a vote against democracy”.

One of the reasons Barrett justified urging Expensify’s clients to vote for Joe Biden is that the company could weather the blowback because it was profitable and taken little outside investment since it was founded. Well, that is something.

In any case, JP Morgan, Citigroup and Bank of America (no Goldman Sachs or Morgan Stanley here) are leading the sale of 9.7m Expensify shares, including 7.1m from selling insiders (Boston’s OpenView Venture Partners is the biggest seller), at $23-$25 for pricing Tuesday, November 9.

The IPO values Expensify at a fully diluted market cap of up to $2.5bn.

Though it sounds a bit more mundane than the way Barrett might describe it, Expensify offers cloud-based software that enables 660,000-plus paid members to automate their expense management by snapping a photo of receipts to sync with accounting software for automatic tracking and payment. Members can also book travel and use the Expensify business credit card for faster reporting and reconciliation, and can also create and send invoices, as well as split bills and request personal payments.

In H1 2021, Expensify reported net income of $14.7m from revenue of $65m, the latter up 60% year-over-year. That said, Covid-19 and associated travel restrictions meant the membership base fell 15% during the worst of the pandemic and remains below the pre-pandemic level of 742,000.

Expensify's filing also includes flash numbers for the September quarter revealing an increase in paid members lifted revenue by as much as 73.3% to $37.6m, though the company expects a net loss of $8.1m-$12.1m for that period due to "one-time special bonus expenses".

In not-so-democratic twist on the super-voting share structure popular among US tech companies, Expensify comes with three classes of stock, the Class A shares sold in the offering, plus "LT10" and "LT50" stock.

Each share of LT10 and LT50 stock is entitled to 10 and 50 votes but cannot be transferred for 10 months and 50 months. This structure concentrates control of the company with a "voting trust", whose trustees are Barrett (the company's CEO), CFO Ryan Schaffer, and Jason Mills, the company's chief product officer.

Notably, Barrett previously led engineering for Red Swoosh, the peer-to-peer file-sharing company co-founded by former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick (apparently not the most sensitive CEO of all time) and bought by Akamai Technologies in 2007.

While living in the Tenderloin in San Francisco, Barrett set out to build a private label electronic food stamp card he could hand out to anyone in need and could be used once a day for up to $10 a day at restaurants that didn't serve alcohol.

Barrett said that idea proved too difficult for banks to embrace, and he instead decided to create a corporate card for small businesses that they could hand out to their employees while keeping the rewards.

"The SMB expense management market is like the land that time forgot—a huge, high margin, largely untapped 'silent majority' of the market that is scraping by with antique solutions. And we are the ones that have created a single, powerful, easy-to-use tool with a viral, word-of-mouth model to capture and modernize it at scale. But expense management alone was never the full plan, just the foundation for what's to come."

Barrett said Expensify had created a “payments superapp”, but the company's long-term vision was to create the first “financial social network”.

He hasn’t forgotten about the little people.

Last year, the company created a charity wing, Expensify.org, that gets a small donation with every swipe of the Expensify card and aims to “create a just and generous world.”

Adventing

Advent International, one of the most seasoned private equity firms and survivor through many cycles, is not done yet after a huge year of monetization activity via US ECM.

Having already taken portfolio companies Olaplex, Sovos Brands, First Watch and Definitive Healthcare public in the US this year, Advent is also the major shareholder of NYSE-bound Brazilian software engineering/digital transformation services firm CI&T.

Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, JP Morgan and Morgan Stanley are marketing 19.4m shares at $17-$19 for pricing next Tuesday, November 9 (the same night as Rivian).

The offering includes 8.3m secondary shares from Advent International and CI&T’s co-founders. Advent will continue to hold at least 46m shares or 41% voting power.

The terms value CI&T at about $2.4bn versus run-rate net revenue of about $245m based on its H1 2021 numbers.

This is familiar territory for ECM participants since CI&T competes with the likes of Endava, Globant and EPAM Systems, all of which have crossed the paths of IPO investors in the past.

Lost in translation

In a potentially ominous sign for future China-to-US listings, cross-border biotech LianBio plunged 14.4% on its Nasdaq debut today following last week’s delay in the pricing of its $325m IPO.

LianBio, which has offices in both Shanghai and New Jersey (somewhat muddying the waters in terms of describing its domicile, though like most Chinese deals it is incorporated in the Caymans), finally gained effectiveness from the SEC late Friday for the sale of 20.3m shares at $16.00.

Unfortunately, this was two days later than planned after the securities watchdog put the deal through the regulatory wringer in what cynics might describe as payback for the Didi Global episode.

Last Wednesday, Goldman Sachs, Jefferies and Bank of America went out with pricing of a fully sized offering at $16.00, the midpoint of the $15-$17 marketing range. They were able to hold the book together at that price despite the SEC’s concerns and plenty of space devoted in the risk factors section to the potential for Chinese interference in its operations.

In March, LianBio raised $310m on a Series A private round led by biotech VCs Perceptive Advisors and RA Capital and supported by crossover investors such as T. Rowe Price and Wellington Investments.

It is believed those crossover investors also participated in the IPO.

Indeed, the banks concentrated allocations with existing shareholders to compensate for a lack of incremental support from new investors.

LianBio closed today at $13.70, though at least it was on relatively light volume of just 2.4m shares ($14.46 one-day VWAP).

LianBio marked the first US IPO with heavy exposure to mainland China since ride hailing giant Didi’s $4.4bn NYSE IPO in late June. Given LianBio’s poor first day of trading, it may take a while before we see another one.

Then again, FWD, a Chinese insurer, seems to be moving ahead with its planned US listing, today filing an amendment after first filing with the SEC in September.

As outlined in the September IPO filing, Apollo Global-affiliate Athene Life still plans to invest $400m concurrent with the IPO through a private placement, with $50m of that investment locked up for 12 months and the rest for 24 months.

FWD and Athene will work together on distribution and reinsurance of insurance.

The private placement is in addition to $500m of commitment from anchor investors on the IPO, including $300m from Lik Ka Shing.

#Lovelulus

Online-only fashion brand Lulu’s Fashion House is hoping its growing social media following among Millennial and Gen Z women will translate into high demand for an up to $109m Nasdaq IPO next week.

Goldman Sachs, Bank of America and Jefferies are marketing 5.8m shares at $16-$19, valuing the women’s clothing brand around $710m.

Lulu’s is part of a new breed of online-only fashion brands steering its customers to its online retail platform through social media. Of its 7.5m social media followers, 2.5m were active customers as of October 3.

To help spread the word, Lulu’s employs a network of social media influencers as brand ambassadors who are paid or receive free products for their endorsements and for using the #lovelulus hashtag.

The company expects to generate a net profit of $3.3m-$3.9m from revenue of $104.5m-$106.3m in the quarter ended September 30, up from a net profit of $0.3m from $54.5m of revenue in Q3 2020.

Lulu’s commands full retail price on most of its products, with a 94% of restocked products sold without moving to sale pricing. Its customers are also loyal, with 65% of sales coming from return customers.

Fashion IPOs can be fickle.

Recent debutantes Rent the Runway (last week) and aka Brands (last month) both stumbled on debut, hanging respective day-one losses of 8.2% and 9.2% on investors.

At the other end of the spectrum, Revolve Group, an online fashion house that uses a similar marketing strategy as Lulu’s, has soared since its IPO in 2019.

Revolve shares closed today at $73.85, up 136% year-to-date.

Bankers will no doubt try to steer investors toward using Revolve as a public comparable for Lulu’s (as opposed to aka or RTR).

Low clearance

No doubt with a fair bit of reverse inquiry, car dealer Asbury Automotive this afternoon launched an equity offering to help fund its recently announced $3.2bn purchase of privately held Larry H. Miller (LHM) Dealerships, having previously outlined plans to sell $1.5bn of new debt and roughly $650m of new stock.

JP Morgan, Bank of America and Wells Fargo are marketing the sale of 3.3m shares for one day tomorrow concurrent with the new debt, the latter comprising eight and 10-year notes.

Asbury agreed to acquire LHM in late September, at the time indicating plans to fund the purchase with $600m of equity and the rest with debt.

The acquisition, which comes amid soaring used car prices through the pandemic, is immediately accretive to earnings but Asbury is hoping to cut net leverage to 3x within 18 to 24 months.

Asbury shares closed today’s session at $202.02, slightly above the $198.82 level ahead of the LHM announcement but down from as high as $230.97 two weeks ago before it reported its Q3 numbers.

The problem was not the quarterly results, as the $215.2m and $2.4bn of adjusted Ebitda and revenue reported both topped estimates. But analysts at JP Morgan said Asbury’s balance sheet was “now maxed out”, leaving “little further catalysts for balance sheet-driven EPS revisions”.

As part of the combo equity-debt financing, Asbury is entering into a new five-year bank facility secured by real estate, taking advantage of $740m worth of real estate inherited as part of the LHM purchase.

All-in, the $3.2bn purchase has elevated net leverage to 4.5x TTM Ebitda.

Links

Coca-Cola to buy remaining stake in sports drink maker Bodyarmor for $5.6bn.

Franklin Templeton to buy secondary private equity asset manager Lexington Partners for $1.75bn.

Goldman Sachs offers new way to bet on SPACs.

Goldman Sachs brings forward forecast for first post-pandemic rate rise to July 2022.

Priced

Monday

LianBio (Cayman Islands/China, biotech) – $325m IPO. 20.3m ADSs (100% prim) at $16.00 versus at $15-$17 marketing. GS, JEFF, BOFA. Nasdaq “LIAN”. Marketing extended from 10/27.

Calendar

Week of November 1: E Automotive (Canada, online auto) – C$125m IPO. 5.4m-6.58m shares (100% prim) at C$19-$23. CGEN, CIBC, NBF, SCOT, EIGHT, ATB, LAUR. TSX “EINC”. Cat Rock Capital Management and Ophir Asset Management have indicated an interest in C$50m of shares. Operating as E Inc.

Week of November 1: Sharethrough (Canada, adtech) – C$75m IPO. 3.95m-5m shares (100% prim) at C$15-$19. RBC, NBF, SCOT, BARC. TSX “STRX”.

November 1: Arbor Realty Trust (US, mortgage REIT) – $149.3m Block. 7.5m shares (100% prim) at $19.70-$19.90 versus $20.73 last sale. JPM, JMP, RJ. Using a portion of money to buyback 562,500 shares from management.

November 1: Compass Therapeutics (US, biotech) – $100m FO. Fixed size (100% prim) versus $3.02 at launch. SVBL. Uplisting to Nasdaq Capital Markets.

November 1: Vertiv (US, electrical components) – $510m Block. 20m shares (100% sec) at $25.00-$25.50 versus $26.05 last sale. JPM, GS, CITI. Platinum Equity is selling stockholder.

November 2: Allbirds (US, consumer goods) – $269.2m IPO. 19.2m shares (80% prim, 20% sec) at $12-$14. MS, JPM, BOFA. Nasdaq “BIRD”. Structured as a public benefit corporation. Franklin Templeton and TDM Growth Partners indicating for $70m of offering. 3% DSP. Up to 6% of IPO to be allocated to retail through Robinhood, Morgan Stanley Wealth Management, SoFi, and Click IPO.

November 2: Asbury Automotive (US, auto dealerships) – $666.7m FO. 3.3m shares (100% prim) versus $202.02 at launch. JPM, BOFA, WF. Concurrent $1.5bn offering of straight debt consisting of eight and 10-year debt.

November 2: Claros Mortgage Trust (US, commercial mortgage REIT) – $137.6m IPO. 7m shares (100% prim) at $18.65-$19.65. MS, JPM, GS, DB, UBS, WF, JMP, KBW. NYSE “CMTG”.

November 2: Delimobil (Russia, car sharing) – $240m IPO. 20m ADSs (100% prim) at $10-$12. BOFA, CITI, VTB. Dual-listing on NYSE “DMOB”, Moscow Exchange “MOEX”. Mikro Kapital.

November 3: Arhaus (US, home furnishings) – $389.3m IPO. 22.9m shares (56% prim, 44% sec) at $14-$17. BOFA, JEFF, MS, PS. Nasdaq “ARHS”. Freeman Spogli & Co portfolio company.

November 3: Cadre (US, tactical equipment) – $80.8m IPO. 5.8m shares (100% prim) at $12-$14. STFL, RJ, BRLY. Nasdaq “CDRE”. Deal was withdrawn on 8/27.

November 3: Evotec (Germany, biotech) – $600m Nasdaq IPO. 22m ADSs (100% prim) versus €23.39/$27.13 launch reference. BOFA, MS, CITI, JEFF, COWN, RBC. Nasdaq “EVO”. Ordinary shares trade on Frankfurt Stock Exchange.

November 3: MDxHealth (Belgium, medical diagnostics) – $50.5m Nasdaq IPO. 3.75m ADSs (100% prim) at $13.46 launch reference. PS, OPCO, BTIG, KBC. Nasdaq “MDXH”. Trades Euronext Brussels "MDXH.BR”.

November 3: NerdWallet (US, fintech) – $137.8m IPO. 7.25m shares (100% prim) at $17-$19. MS, KEYB, BOFA, BARC, CITI. Nasdaq “NRDS”.

November 4: Cian (Russia, online real estate) – $291.4m IPO. 18.2m ADSs (22% prim, 78% sec) at $13.50-$16.00. MS, GS, JPM, BOFA, RENC, VTB. NYSE “CIAN”. Intends to list ADSs on Moscow Exchange “MOEX”.

November 4: Desert Peak Minerals (US, E&P royalty trust) – $230m IPO. 10m shares (100% prim) at $20-$23. BARC, CS, UBS. NYSE “DPM”. 5% DSP. CEO Christopher Conoscenti intends to participate in IPO.

November 4: IO Biotech (Denmark, biotech) – $110.5m IPO. 6.5m shares (100% prim) at $14-$17. MS, JEFF, COWN. Nasdaq “TCBX”.

November 4: Real Good Food Co (US, frozen foods) – $85.3m IPO. 5.3m shares (100% prim) at $14-$16. JEFF, WBLR, TRST, NOM. Nasdaq “RGF”.

November 8: Third Coast Bancshares (US, bank) – $78m IPO. 3m shares (100% prim) at $24-$26. STPH, PS, DB. Nasdaq “TCBX”.

November 9: CI&T (Brazil, engineering software) – $369.4m IPO. 19.4m shares (57% prim, 43% sec) at $17-$19. GS, CITI, JPM, MS. NYSE “CINT”.

November 9: Expensify (US, enterprise software) – $243.3m IPO. 9.7m shares (27% prim, 73% sec) at $23-$25. JPM, CITI, BOFA. Nasdaq “EXFY”.

November 9: Rivian Automotive (US, electric vehicles) – $8.4bn IPO. 135m shares (100% prim) at $57-$62. MS, GS, JPM. Nasdaq “RIVN”. Cornerstone investors have indicated for $5bn. 7% DSP to US customers with outstanding pre-orders as of September 30.

November 10: Lulu’s Fashion Lounge (US, retailer) – $109.3m IPO. 5.75m shares (100% prim) at $16-$19. GS, BOFA, JEFF.Nasdaq “LVLU”. DSP. Principal Global indicating for $15m of offering.

Registered IPO backlog

November: Agendia (Netherlands, diagnostics) – $75m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). GS, CITI, COWN, STFL. Nasdaq “AGDX”.

November: Ambrx Biopharma (Cayman Islands/US, biotech) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). GS, BOFA, COWN. NYSE “AMAM” ADS offering.

November: Artiva Biotherapeutics (US, biotech) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). GS, COWN, EVER, CGEN. Nasdaq “RTVA”.

November: Authentic Brands (US, brand licensing) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). BOFA, JPM, GS, JEFF, UBS. NYSE “AUTH”.

November: Backblaze (US, software) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). OPCO, WBLR, RJ. Nasdaq “BLZE”.

November: Braze (US, software) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (prim, sec). GS, JPM, BARC, PS, WBLR. Nasdaq “BRZE”.

November: BrightSpring Health Services (US, healthcare) – $500m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). GS, JEFF, KRR, CS, GUGG, SVBL. Nasdaq “”. Concurrent mandatory convertible offering. Portfolio company of KKR, Walgreens Boots Alliance.

November: Castle Creek Biosciences (US, biotech) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). CITI, PS, BARC. Nasdaq “CCBS”.

November: Chicago Atlantic Real Estate Finance (US, cannabis REIT) – $129.4m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). JMP, COMP, OPCO. Nasdaq “REFI”. Management investing through concurrent private placement.

November: Claire’s (US, retail) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). GS, CITI. NYSE “CLRS”. MS removed as JB on 10/27.

November: Daojia Limited (China, home services) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). JPM, UBS, CICC. NYSE “JIA”.

November: Everside Health (US, primary healthcare provider) – $500m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). MS, JPM, GS, BOFA, WBLR. NYSE “EVSD”.

November: ForU Worldwide (China, freight-as-a-service) – $500m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). GS, UBS, CICC. Nasdaq “FOYO”.

November: FWD (Hong Kong, life insurance) – $3bn IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). MS, GS, JPM. NYSE “FWD”. Backed with up to $500m of demand, including $300m from affiliates of Pacific Century Group. Athene/Apollo investing up to $400m in a concurrent private placement.

November: Freehold Properties (US, cannabis REIT) – $115m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). STFL, COWN. Nasdaq “FHP”.

November: Fresh Market (US, grocery retail) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). CS, BOFA, BARC, DB, RBC, BMO, GUGG. Nasdaq “TFM”. Apollo portfolio company.

November: Gerson Lehrman (US, expert networks) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). MS, GS, BOFA, BARC, JEFF, BAIRD, WBLR. Nasdaq “GLGX”.

November: Hertz Global (US, car rental) – $100m Nasdaq IPO. Terms TBD (100% sec). GS, JPM, MS, BARC, DB. Nasdaq “HTZ”. Uplisting from OTC shares trading under “HTZZ” at $25.70 at file.

November: Hexion (US, specialty chemicals) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). MS. NYSE “HXN”. Shares trade on OTC Pink Sheets under “HXOH” at $21.00 a share.

November: iCIMS (US, cloud software) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). MS, JPM, CITI. Nasdaq “TLNT”.

November: Intermedia Cloud Communications (US, communication-as-a-service) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). MS, JPM, CS, EVER, JEFF. Nasdaq “INTM”. NEC Corp investing $40m through concurrent private placement. 5% DSP. Madison Dearborn portfolio company.

November: Intuity Medical (US, diagnostics) – $75m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). GS, JEFF, PS. Nasdaq “POGO”.

November: Iris Energy (Australia, bitcoin mining) – $100m IPO. Terms TBD (100% prim). JPM, CGEN, CITI. Nasdaq “IREN”.
